    A & E Example Combine Example Date Merging Logging Example Prescribing Example

    Function reference

    All functions

    adjust_date_format()
    Adjust date formats to DD-MM-YYYY
    check_for_nested()
    Check if a filter is nested or single
    chk_pth()
    Check to see if provided spec is path or a JSON string.
    coerce_dates()
    Coerce YYYYMMDD columns in a data frame to dates where possible, using lubridate::ymd. This function only converts columns where every value successfully coerces to a date.
    context_message()
    Concatenate context into string and append a message
    eider eider-package
    eider: Todo Acronym Has Not Been Decided
    eider_example()
    Return path to the example datasets provided with the package
    error_context()
    Issue an error with a context and stop
    error_not_string()
    Helper function
    featurise()
    Extract a feature table using a feature JSON file.
    featurise_combine()
    Computes the combination of two or more features.
    featurise_count()
    Computes the number of rows per patient ID which contain specific values in specific columns.
    featurise_lookup()
    Generates a feature which simply takes values from a named column from a source table. If a patient has multiple rows in the source table, the feature table will contain the value from the first row.
    featurise_present()
    Generates a feature which, for each patient ID, contains a 1 if any row that passes a specified filter exists, or 0 if not.
    featurise_sum()
    Groups by ID and computes the sum of the values in all rows which pass a given filter.
    featurise_time_since()
    First passes a table through a filter, then counts the time between a given date and the first OR last date in the filtered table.
    featurise_unique()
    Groups by ID and computes the number of distinct values in all rows which pass a given filter.
    filter_all()
    Pass table through any type of filter.
    filter_and()
    Filter table rows based on a logical conjunction of multiple filters (i.e. filter1 AND filter2 AND ...)
    filter_basic()
    Generic function for a basic filter, parametrised over the type of comparison operator used to select rows.
    filter_basic_date()
    Generic function for a basic filter, parametrised over the type of comparison operator used to select rows. The values to be taken are dates instead of numbers, though.
    filter_not()
    Filter table rows based on a logical negation of a filter (i.e. NOT filter1)
    filter_or()
    Filter table rows based on a logical disjunction of multiple filters (i.e. filter1 OR filter2 OR ...)
    join_feature_tables()
    Join feature tables together.
    json_to_feature()
    Take the json input file and produce a formatted R object which can direct the filters
    pad_missing_values()
    Given an ID column in a table, and a missing value, appends id-value pairs for all values that are not in a second table. It is assumed that the IDs are added to the 'id' column in the second table.
    parse_nested_filter()
    Parse a nested filter, returns a list of type (AND/OR) followed by lists of the singular filters
    parse_single_feature()
    Parse the header information from the json file to our targed feature object
    parse_single_filter()
    Parse a single (un-nested) filter and return a list with data column name filter type, and the limiting values
    parse_single_or_nested()
    Check if a filter is nested or single and parse accordingly
    preprocess_table()
    Perform (date) preprocessing on a given data table
    read_data()
    Process the list of tables given, returning a list of tibbles. Each entry in the list can either be a tibble itself (or a data.frame), or a string, in which case it is assumed to be a file and is read in.
    read_one_table()
    Helper function to read a single table from a file.
    read_spec_type()
    Read spec type and give appropriate logging messages
    trace_context() trace_context()
    Log a TRACE message showing the current execution context
    transform()
    Perform the entire feature transformation process.
    validate_absent_default_value()
    Checks that spec$absent_default_value is a single number. If so, returns the number.
    validate_column_present()
    Checks that spec[[field_name]] is a single string and that it is a column in the table tbl. If so, returns the column name.
    validate_filter_column()
    Checks that the column specified by a filter object exists in a table. If so, returns the column name.
    validate_filter_value()
    Checks that the values specified by a filter object are of the same type as the column to be filtered on. If so, returns the values.
    validate_output_feature_name()
    Checks that spec$output_feature_name is a single string. If so, returns the string.
    validate_source_file()
    Checks that spec$source_file is a single string and that it is a key in all_tables. If so, returns the table itself (or the file path of the table).

    Developed by Camila Rangel Smith, Helen Duncan Little, Jonathan Yong.

    Site built with pkgdown 2.0.7.
